bioghist.p: Walter H. Blumenthal (1883-1969) was a historian whose subjects included the American colonial and revolutionary periods, Native Americans, bibliomania, and Shakespeare authorship. He received his bachelor's degree from the University of Pennsylvania in 1903. His published works include Women Camp Followers of the American Revolution, Paging Mr. Shakespeare, and In Old America: Random Chapters on the Early Aborigines.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Walter H. Blumenthal. Materials include a notebook containing Blumenthal's entrance examination to the University of Pennsylvania on the subject of Greek and Roman history, 1899, with maps and a plan; a binder of typescripts of poetry entitled "Exit Laughing"; a bibliography of Blumenthal's early writings (1919-1938); a collection of typescript stories, lightly annotated, with a preface by Louis Golding, circa 1930; photostats of a catalog of the sale of the Stowe collection (including a Shakespeare portrait); a copy of "Spurious Shakespeare Portraiture," an article by Blumenthal, reprinted from The American Book Collector, 1960; and negatives and photographs of prints, paintings, and sculptures of Shakespeare.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
